ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The knowledge of currency exchanges and international markets.
info about international economics, exchange rates, debt, policy options for recessions, etc
learned about exchange rates, GDP, international trade, foreign direct investment, differential development based on international financial flows

I learned a lot about the integration between different countries and their economies. I also learned how the policies in OCED countries can impact developing countries and how we can do better in the future.
A sense of the international financial landscape, as well as new economic models / concepts
This is a really informative class on how international trade, exchange rates work that touches also a little bit on development economics.
Understanding of the important of exchange rates and how exchange rates relate to various economic indicators. Overview of policy tools and history of monetary systems.

Gained an understanding of international good, service, and asset markets. Learned about different exchange rate regimes, strategies for capital controls, international debt markets, etc. Learned about the history of international finance, including the stuggles faced by developing countries, and the question of optimal currency unions.
I really enjoyed taking this course, particularly learning how applicable the course material is to the current economic environment.
Interest trades, forex, sovereign debt.
Discussion of a few foreign exchange models, with strong focus on one large model.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Weaknesses were the math needed to complete some of the assignments/assessments was not always taught (could use refresser)
strengths: helpful slides and prof is great, weaknesses: don't need to pay attention to most of the material to do well so easy to zone out
Big lecture course, which would be improved in a seminar style format with more frequent student engagement and problem sets
Strengths: low workload, interesting lectures

Strengths: Does a good job of connecting abstract models with real world data and news. Very smart professor and TA

Weaknesses: Assignment timelines a bit irregular; minimal office hours; also minimal materials to prepare for exams except for the final
Professor is a huge strength, can't say enough good things about her.

Strengths: very interesting and well organized

Improvements: would appreciate more practice problems / real life application opportunities

Strengths: I learned so much from this course. I see articles regularly that I would not have understood without this course. International finance is a fascinating and complex field.

Weaknesses: Before every exam, it felt like kind of a surprise what we were going to be tested on. In particular, the final exam that covered lectures 7-13 was almost exclusively on Lecture 7. This made studying in advance somewhat futile. Only after the review session (2 days prior to the exam), could we really study effectively.

The course was structured well, engaging, and properly challenging. I think the course could potentially benefit from more frequent but shorter problem sets, which wouldn't increase the workload but would more evenly distribute student engagement in the course.

I think the lectures could be a little more clear. I felt like on multiple occasions the information was incorrect and had to be corrected. I figured out half way through the semester that the textbook is very helpful to read and wish I had been doing that from the start.
Sometimes disorganized, but good availability for questions

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes if ECON major and skilled at math for HW assignments
yes if you need a chill econ senior seminar. also really nice it didn't have a final exam but instead 3 midterms
Yes, Prof Fieler was a great teacher, and the material was easy to learn and engaging. A great senior seminar and I liked the 3 midterm format.
Yes if you are interested in learning about international finance and trade, no if you're looking for a super engaging or intellectually stimulating course
Definitely! Take any course with Ana Fieler!
I would if they are interested in understanding economics from a global perspective; however, I would share the courses weaknesses with them as well.

Yes, great class if you enjoy Macroeconomics! Professor Fieler is awesome. 

This class is more about analyzing different exchange rate regimes and the monetary system in both developing and developed countries rather than a typical finance class.
I would recommend it with caution. I learned so much, but felt disappointed by the exams and how they didn't always test my full range of knowledge.

Yes, I think the class covers topics that are very important to understand in the world we live in today. It is well taught, and you leave the course wiht a much greater understanding of international financial markets.
This is an okay course for a senior econ elective. It isn't a ton of work if that's what you're looking for, but I don't think it is taught very well. You need to be reading the textbook.
